title: 3D Printed Watch Mainspring for Smaller Print Beds (UNTESTED)

description.text: This is a redesigned mainspring for @TheGoofy's 3D-Printed Watch with Tourbillion. My Rep2X only has 150mm on the Y-axis, so I needed to redesign the mainspring to fit in the print area. I did my best to keep the length of the coil the same. @TheGoofy's spring was ~2117mm long as best I can tell. v1 one is ~2096mm. v1.1 is ~2119mm. I have not printed or tested it. I am waiting for the shafts and screws to arrive before I start building one of my own. This could be completely wrong. I own't know until I get further into replicating @TheGoofy's awesome build. You can find the model on OnShape for now, until I decide to clean up my OnShape documents and delete the model someday. You can adjust the helixes in OnShape to adjust the length, but you just need to make sure the number of turns on each helix matches up with the start angle of the next helix. i just adjust the outermost helix to tweak the overall length of the spring. Your mileage may vary. If you decide to print this, just be aware that it might not fit and might not work! P.S. If anyone knows why I can't post comments on Thingiverse, please let me know!

author: Nate_the_Ace

print_settings.Infill:: 15%, hexagonal.  But the infill really doesn't matter.  Use whatever you like.

description.text:
Three-path Dice Tower, now with stone-like surface!
This is a dice tower based loosely on Laura's Tower in Shrewsbury. All the components are to be connected using disc magnets. Here's a link of it in action https://youtu.be/Yud55mL8Ov8 I used texturelib.com's brick_pavement_0060 image to make an svg in Inkscape. Then I imported the svg into Autodesk Fusion 360, and extruded it into a solid. This solid was then used to cut stonework into the surface. I also took shawngeise's (http://www.thingiverse.com/shawngiese/about) advice, and made the top "dice-dumpable". Thanks, shawngiese! 2017-03-23 update: Due to demand, I have uploaded a one-piece tower section. The stairs are still detachable. 2017-03-29 update: Why not? I just uploaded an all-in-one stl file that includes the stairs as well as the tower. All in one. 2017-04-03 update: check out the improvements on this make!
Very nicely done! http://www.thingiverse.com/make:321708 2017-05-09 update: At the suggestion of http://www.thingiverse.com/doctordavemorgan, here is a flat top for use as terrain (Hex_Platfrom.stl). It has a 1" hex grid embossed into the surface. Thanks, DoctorDaveMorgan! 2017-05-10 update: I've been meaning to do this for months: A 3rd floor! I didn't really like the proportions of the tower. So I've created a third floor, to go between the 2nd and top floor. In the interest of terrain use, I added three castellated balconies to it, each of which should be able to hold a figurine. If you printed the full tower, I apologize. If you printed the modular tower, this section will click right into place. If you wanted to make a ridiculously tall tower, print and stack multiples. Of course, the dice will shoot out like rockets after dropping that far ;) 2017-05-11 update: I re-generated the stone texture (used to "stamp" the texture on the outside of the tower) and have uploaded it. 2017-07-18 update: I finally made a base to keep the dice captive! the file is here, and the base (a remix of devonjones' dungeon tiles) is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2441719 2017-08-01 update: There's now a poorly-shot video of the tower & base in action here: https://youtu.be/UM9lduOIe2k

Printer:

Wilson II

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 micron

Infill:

15%, hexagonal. But the infill really doesn't matter. Use whatever you like.

Notes: I also used 3 perimeters. I didn't use any brim, since the heated bed glass (60°) + elmer's purple glue stick holds the part down really well. Personally, I use Slic3r. I like it.

Assembling the thingy I used ordinary Cyanoacrylate Glue (Gorilla brand superglue to be precise) to fix the magnets into the holes. It also helped that the holes were a snug fit on my magnets. I used parchment paper (silicone-impregnated cooking paper stuff) on my desk top to avoid ruining the desk. I first "buttered up" the inside of the hole with glue, placed the magnet on top of the parchment paper, and pressed the tower segment down over the magnet, forcing it into the hole. The desk surface (which is protected by the parchment paper) made sure that the magnet was flush with the surface. I also made sure that each section had at least one magnet pair mounted the "other way". This meant that the sections snapped together in only one orientation. If all the magnets in a tower section were north-south (instead of north-south, north-south, south-north), then the tower could possibly go together facing ±120° in the wrong orientation. To avoid any mistakes, I only did "one side" of each magnet pair using the "force the magnet in using the desk surface" technique. After the glue finished setting up, I laid parchment paper over the section with the magnet already glued in, then placed the matching magnet on top. then I "buttered up" the holes in the mating section, and pressed that section over the magnets held in place by the already-glued section. This way, I made no north-south mistakes, and the tower segments are perfectly aligned.
.

comments.text: All good, I fully respect you wishes and will not make your design available for sale anywhere. For what it's worth I was only going to make a couple of them available here locally and only charge for the material costs and of course FULL credit would have gone to you for the design as well as the fact that it can be downloaded for print from this site for free, I wasn't going to go into full production for Ebay or anything like that :-) Anyway on the subject of designing my own I am currently working on 3DS Max and have a few ideas of my own for something similar and again my hat goes off to you for an excellent piece of CAD design. I have only recently joined the world of 3D printing and I think this site is an awesome community of very talented people and this is why I asked first as I am not a thief of intellectual property, as my profession I am an Audio Engineer, I own my own music studio here in Melbourne and deal with very sensitive clients when it comes to their music and was taught quite extensively about this when I studied for my Diploma back in 1994. I will be sure to upload my finished and painted print in the next couple of days and I hope you will enjoy seeing another one of your designs finished in a different way (just about to start the stairs and I'm done). So far your files have printed perfectly and I know from my limited experience that this is not an easy task. Sorry for the big rant but I just wanted you to know that I am not someone who is trolling these types of sites looking to cash in on someone else's hard work. Cheers again from down under and keep up the great work!!!!

Notes: Used 2.65 m of white PLA. Colored first part with yellow Sharpie. Switched to red at 52% complete and (accidentally) back to white at 95%. Took about 1.5 hours.
Removed some artifacts with a pair of tweezers and lightly sanded.

Our media center circulates at lot of SD cards to students.  A LOT of SD cards.  To keep them organized and accessible, and to keep them at a relatively consistent use cycle, I designed this wall-mountable dispenser.  Returned cards are dropped in at the top, and a single new card can be pulled from the bottom.  The slot at the bottom is tapered to make it easier for your finger to pull the card.  I've uploaded three different designs: two-slot, three-slot, and four-slot.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: You'll need to print supports for the slot at the bottom at the mounting holes. No raft should be necessary. I printed mine at 0.2mm with 20% infill, but you can tweak this to fit your printer's personality as needed. The base and walls are all 2mm thick, if that helps.
The mounting holes are 3mm, which is more than big enough for pushpins on a bulletin board, but you can drill them out or mount them however works best for you.

title: Hub Bub - Wind Power (2016 Science Olympiad)

description.text: This is a very simple Wind Power wind turbine for the 2016 division C Science Olympiad. It should be fully rules complaint but check dimensions before using this design. The Hub Bub is an easy to attach hub that allows 1/8" wooden dowels to be used to attach fins to the CD. The Super Hub Bub is the same, it just supports 8 dowels instead of 4. Note that you will need a printer able to print thing fairly dimensionally accurate or you will spend a lot of time either gluing or sanding the dowels. The dowels should be firm while in place but still removable. Helpful note, glue to the 'shiny' side of the CD. Note: At time of upload, the design has not been tested in competition and has no guarantee of performance. ==================================================================== Printed Parts needed: 1x Hub Bub -or- 1x Super Hub Bub ==================================================================== Hardware Needed: 1x 1/8" Dowel Rod 48" long 1x Super Glue 1x Standard CD

title: Clunky Clock - It's About Time (2016 Science Olympiad)

description.text:
This is a very simple It's About Time metronome / pendulum clock for the 2016 division C Science Olympiad. It should be fully rules complaint but check dimensions before using this design. The Clunky Clock is designed to use parts I have on hand to make a low friction pendulum clock. The 2x4 attachment allow the design to be attached to a simple 2x4 stand. This is not designed to be fancy in any way, it's designed to be functional. Pro Tip: if you use any pendulum clock in the It's about Time event, make sure you can and do start the pendulum in the same place every run. Note: At time of upload, the design has not been tested in competition and has no guarantee of performance. ==================================================================== Printed Parts needed: 1x Penny Holder 1x Arrow 1x Bearing Block 1x 2x4 Attachment ==================================================================== Hardware Needed: 1x 623-2rs Bearing http://www.amazon.com/Bearing-623-2RS-3x10-Sealed-3x10x4/dp/B002BBMG3A 2x M3 Screws (I used M3x16) http://www.amazon.com/16mm-Socket-Machine-Screw-Black/dp/B00W97MTII ~20x M3 Nuts http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NBIH92/ 4x M3 12mm Bolts: http://www.amazon.com/Makerbeam-Bolts-Square-Head-25pcs/dp/B00OXR1X5C 8x M3 6mm Bolts:
http://www.amazon.com/MakerBeam-bolts-square-head-pack/dp/B00G2DNW3G/
or
http://www.amazon.com/MakerBeam-bolts-wing-type-head/dp/B00G2DNWK4/
1x 300mm Makerbeam (you can use any length that you wish, but different lengths will have a different period) http://www.amazon.com/MakerBeam-300mm-beam-black-anodised/dp/B00G2DNU4M 1x 150mm Makerbeam (you can use any size you wish, this is just used to attach the pendulum to the 2x4 base) http://www.amazon.com/MakerBeam-150mm-beam-black-anodised/dp/B00G2DNT4I United States Pennies (as many as you want or need)

author: madi0922

description.header:
Version 4: Finished!
At the moment there is no working mouthpiece compartment, so the one inside the FM will have to be used until V5. Check the progress videos, shots and updates over at my blog, crayprints.tumblr.com. New features include decreased width and increased length of the baggy holes on both sides of the unit. This will allow baggys to actually fit in them. Also there are now lids for all compartments including baggy holes to reduce scent. There are lids for the 3 tool slots on top and the base where the flowermate snugly fits. There are now pegs for more stability as if you use a whip to the dock as I do; you'll find the weight distribution isn't enough to pass a whip among friends if you have a stiff tube for your whip, I have since purchased a desktop vaporizer called the Da Buddha and it's whip tube is flexible and retains it's shape. So I haven't had that problem since however those of you who do use standard FDA approved food tubes; the larger infill percentage print setting (50-100%) and legitimate bronze infill filament material can fix this problem as they are the biggest contributors.
description.text:
I have now completed the design for the third version of the flowermate dock. Visual design has changed drastically since last version mainly due to switching to different modelling software. No more squareish look, now rounded and modern. There are 2 deep pockets within the shoulders, to contain whatever you please; I store my herbs in there. There are 3 small storage holes for stock brush, stock cleaning tool and stock mouthpiece.
The print settings up to you, I print in wood at 200C (light sandwood texture) - 230C (Crispy/Darker texture). I print using CTC.

remixed_from.title: LED Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal

title: LED Strip Light for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text: Based on the LED Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal by Sibanamush. I simplified his design to use LED strip lighting instead of individual LEDs. The entire part is one piece and includes a skirt for blocking stray light and zip-tie holes to prevent the wire from pulling on the strip itself. The part is designed to be a friction-fit onto the printer's Y-Arm. You may need to scale the print slightly to get it to fit well. I used "LE 12V DC Flexible LED Strip Lights" purchased from Amazon for the lights themselves, soldered to 22 AWG wire. The strip is adhesive-backed, but I added a few dabs of epoxy for good measure.

title: 12MM linear rail/rod clamp bolt sleeve  M4 bolt in 5mm diameter hole

description.text: This is a combination adapter sleeve and washer for fitting a M4 bolt snugly in the 12MM rod mounts available from aliexpress. These can be used with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1257251 to fit the aluminium 12mm linear rail rod clamp.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm layer or better

Notes: I used my 2mm shell config so they print solid. I ran my printer really slow and printed 8 at once to prevent melting from printing layers too fast. I used a brim mainly as a carrier so the unused ones don't get lost however I don't think these need a brim to stay attached to the bed.
I used ABS printed on acetone/ABS slurry on borosilicate glass, Bed=110C Extruder 255C. The ABS I used is rated 220C - 260C. printing it hot gets great layer bonding.

I used openscad and used the MCAD/polyholes.scad library to make the hole for the bolt the correct size.
I basically measured everything with a cheap pair of digital vernier callipers The taper is intended to mirror the chamfered edge of the hole in the 12MM aluminium rod clamp. I should have done an array of them in openscad to avoid the need to copy them inside repetier host.

title: Cane Creek Forty Headset Installation Tool

description.text:
Installation tool for installing Cane Creek 40 headset. Make one Crown tool and 2 Bearing Cup tools. You will need to also have the following items.
PVC 1.25 inner diameter
Threaded rods 5/8 Long enough for your head tube
2 5/8 Nuts
2 Large washers
Grease

  • Install crown race on fork. Make sure the area on the fork for the race has been prepped. Use plenty of grease. Use PVC to drive.

  • Install one bearing cup first. Then the other. Use plenty of grease.
    • Only use this procedure if you are comfortable working on bikes. This is the poor mans procedure for installing a headset.

description.text:
I needed some way to kill the noise of my extruder stepper motor when it was doing retractions so I came up with this. Before I would not print models that required lots of retractions because it drove me crazy or kept me awake when I was trying to sleep. Now I can't hardly hear the retractions at all and not at all during regular extrusions.
My extruder is mounted on top of my enclosure so it was vibrating through the entire box and was really loud. For this application I used the soft version. I also printed some stiffer ones to set my printer on and now it is so quiet I can have it run all night and sleep with no problems.
The number in the model name is the height (unloaded) from top surface to bottom. If you need one that is a different height just ask and I will upload one. OR if someone wants to take this idea and make a customizer model that would be cool. I looked at Openscad and no way am I going to type in my model using text. That is modeling from the 70s, although much updated.

description.text:
This is a placeholder for all of the files needed for my 3D printer updates. This covers:
  • Hot End upgrade to E3Dv6 Direct (from J-Head)
  • Y Axis upgrade to remove some wobble with the Drylin-Extrusion design
  • Printable T-Slot nuts
  • Enclosure for entire printer to help maintain better environment for printing
    • Found a t-slot scad generator on thingiverse; can't remember where. it was a simple script and worked for my needs. I've updated it with a basic additional functionality I needed. Sadly I haven't added comments to it but its simple enough to quickly figure out. Made my own Y-axis rod holder design quickly done via OpenScad. Will need to print up 8 of those in total (they sandwhich the 8mm rod). I'm missing the lm8uu bearing holders for my y-axis plate - will add when they are designed up. I actually found a cheap chunk of 5/16" 304 Stainless rod at Fastenal (~$6 for 80 inches) and will be utilizing that with the lm8uu bearings. I didn't expect the rod to fit very tightly but apparently 5/16 rod is almost exactly interchangeable with 8mm (they are 1/16 of a mm different OD). This is not a precision ground rod and as such might be prone to inaccuracy. However I think it'll be a huge upgrade from the current situation where my Drylin allows a little over a 1/16th of an inch movement on the Z axis of the platen. So when the printer shoves the plate around and the X axis gets whipping around the platen can literally shake up/down at its edges. No wonder I get some waves here and there...! When I get the Y axis carriage attachments drawn up I'll post them here. They are intended to be placed to the outer corners of the platen for the best stability in all directions. However I have one of the larger 320mm build plates and presently have an OD of about 460mm for the MendelMax frame. So... this leads me to some math as to how far on the Y axis I can place my carriage if I want to keep it low profile (save z-axis movement area). This means that I can use about 65% of the Y-axis to place my linear bearing mounts (carriage) and still stay just within my frame with the linear bearings. This will avoid collisions, allow a good connection with the end stop switch and give at least the same if not better y-axis range of motion AND stability than I currently have. Since I'll be using these rods at the outer edges of the platen; the platen will be even more stable from side to side motion. I'm also hoping that the bed won't shift "level" as often when I get a little too vigorous with part removal. The files for the E3D hotend swap are directly from Ultibots; the micro extruder and other x-axis components. Will be testing these files once the hotend ships. they are untested as of now.

description.text: One of the most useful but hardest to find bits of pegboard hardware is the pliers holder, like the one pictured. It's very simple, but all the hardware stores I've visited only have them in these huge assortment packs with way too many of other hooks you don't need. I've found a few sources to buy them online separately from these assortment packs (e.g., http://www.hardwarestore.com/plier-holder-pegboard-hook-us2c-628413.aspx), but the shipping prices always make it ludicrous. So, here's my homemade one. The design is a little different from the metal ones, both for strength and ease of 3D printing, but the effect should be the same. This is sized for a type A pegboard (1/4" spacing).

You'll need to print with supports; be careful while cutting them away to avoid weakening or breaking the legs.  I'm stumped for a way to avoid supports on this and still have it have the strength to hold up pliers.

description.text:
English: This spool is designed to fit on the default filament holder (raw 8 mm screw...) of the Renkforce RF1000 printer. Filament rolls with an inner diameter down to 5 cm and a thickness of up to approx. 9.5 cm can be used. It needs to be equipped with two standard skate board ball bearings (8 mm inner / 22 mm outer diameter). Assembly suggestion on the 8 mm screw: 1 washer, 2 hex nuts, 1 small washer, 1 ball bearing, printed spool, 1 ball bearing, 1 small washer, 2 hex nuts. All washers are optional.
Deutsch: Diese Spule passt auf den Original Filament-Halter des Renkforce RF1000 (eine simple 8 mm-Schraube...). Geeignet für Filamentrollen mit einem Innendurchmesser von mindestens 5 cm und einer Maximalbreite von ca. 9,5 cm. Die gedruckte Spule muss nur noch mit zwei Standard-Skateboard-Kugellagern bestückt werden (8 mm/22 mm Innen-/Aussendurchmesser). Zusammenbautipp auf der 8mm-Schraube (ab Plexiglas): Beilagscheibe, zwei Muttern, kleine Beilagscheibe, Kugellager, gedruckte Spule, Kugellager, kleine Beilagscheibe, zwei Muttern. Die Beilagscheiben sind optional.

Printer:

RF1000

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

0.2 mm

25%

author: circulus

description.text: These are cupcake endstop mounts for the Gen 4 electronics endstops. (http://store.makerbot.com/mechanical-endstop-v1-2.html) I wanted endstop mounts that did not require me to drill holes in my cupcake. These are the -x and -y mounts for the original x and y axis. (not lowrider)

Using 4 3mm x 25mm Screws you can remove the top two bolts on the X front retaining bracket and insert the 25mm screws in their place. the X axis mounts onto these screws with the previous nuts. Then remove the front left bearing holding screws and replace with the 25mm screws with the Y axis mount on the bottom surface of the bot. Attach the endstops to the two holes in the top of each mount using 2 3mm x 10mm screws per mount, these do not require nuts as the holes are undersized to allow them to bite into the mount. I mounted the z endstop using a hole for the extruder board and an existing random hole in the side of the bot.

description.text:
This is a small table soccer game for 2 people.
You can either print the court and the goals as one piece, or as single pieces (if you want to use different colors).
If you have printed every piece, stick the goals to the court, put the player into the holders and fix them with the attachment. Before sticking the attachment to the court, make sure that the players are mobile. If they were not, sand the holes in the holder and the attachment a bit until you can move the players. I recommend using superglue for sticking the things together.
If you have a small Lego football at home or any other round object with a diameter of about 1cm you can use these for playing instead of the printed ball.

title: Sharpie holder for Ultimate Filament Colorer

description.text:
The Ultimate Filament Colorer by beebenutz is the technique of colouring filament by passing it through the ink sponge inside a Sharpie marker before it feeds into the hotend. The pigment mixes with the plastic inside the hotend, producing a permanent colour that doesn't rub off. If you want to try this out, I wrote a comprehensive guide to the technique here. I've also documented the colours you get when you colour white PLA with Sharpie ink here. This holder was made to complement the technique. It does three jobs:
  • It holds the Sharpie vertically so that the filament can pass through it and into the extruder with as little kinking — and friction — as possible.
  • You can use it as a colour swatch if you print it in the colour of the Sharpie it will hold, as I did in the photo above.
  • You can use it to store the Sharpie after use. Put the cap on the end so that it covers the hole you drilled into the bottom of the Sharpie. Put a piece of tape or putty over the filament exit hole at the bottom of the holder.

• Standard Sharpie holder is the one shown in the photos. It is 40 mm tall.
  • Short Sharpie holder is 25 mm tall and, of course, prints faster than the taller Standard version.
  • Tray for Sharpie holders stores 5×2 Sharpies tip-down with their holders, which is how Sharpies are meant to be stored. It keeps your palette together and makes it easy to see and choose a colour.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10

The injection molding flashing around the Sharpie's barrel makes its outer diameter quite variable. I used a Knife Edge Reamer to widen the opening in this model just enough to make a very tight fit around it. You can also sand or trim the barrel, but the reamer is much faster and cleaner. You will be able to see the Sharpie bottom-out inside the holder if correctly fitted.

27 Jan 2016
  • Uploaded the short holder.
  • Uploaded the holder tray.
    • 16 Jan 2016
  • Initial release.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5kGjhb6dqqC-sharpie-holder-for-ultimate-filament-colorer

A screwdriver for a regular 1/4" bit-holder. It has a spring locking feature to prevent the bit-holder from falling out. This is not made for short bits: they will plunge into the hole completely. The hexagon hole has a diameter of 1/4" +200µm.
I could not find such a simple thing in my local hardware store. There were only sets consisting of huge screwdrivers and bits. Probably 10€ saved. Welcome to the new world old industry.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Use a huge brim (i.e. 10mm) and print with the hexagonal hole facing upwards. Don't use supports. You may want to use higher infill percentage for higher break resistance. Furthermore in my case black PLA is much stronger than grey PLA.
You may need to push in and pull out the bit holder a few times to smoothen the inner surfaces and allow for easy bit holder removal.

title: Large spool to small spool sewing machine solution

description.text: On my Bernina sewing machine I wanted to spool a large spool (from a serger) onto the bobbin spool. Best way is to fix the big spool at the table plane, and pull off the wire to the top. A helpful part that can be placed at the position of your normal spool is this two element 3D printed part.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Notes: I printed one component with support everywhere, and one with only a brim. Both work. Finishing of the overhanging parts is better when using support everywhere.
You can print the small part first to see if it fits your diameter of spool holder. Print all parts with their biggest diameter to the bottom side of course!

Click the two parts together.
Bend a wire in the shape that you see in the picture. Bending around the spool holder gives a good basic shape. Insert the wire in the printed part.
Can optionally be glued in place. A hot melt glue gun works fine for that.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

A variation of Gaël's InMoov robot hand (http://inmoov.fr/).
With the help of an orientation sensor (adafruit bno055), an android nano, an additional servo and some modifications on the original parts this hand will keep its level when in it's mechanical range. Here is the video of the final result https://www.youtube.com/watch?edit=vd&v=nnjBYmTVjLc and here the details for building it http://snaptip.com/ezq1qa8d2g/inmoov-self-levelling-hand

I love to work with OpenScad!
Where possible I used the import function of OpenScad to be able to start with the original part designed by Gaël.
From there it was removing and adding parts until it looked and worked as needed for my added function.

description.text:
2017-04-21 added 1 tire for the wider rear 2017 wheel ‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾
PLEASE RESPECT THE LICENSE AND GIVE CREDIT TO THE DESIGNER!
‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾
These friction tires will hopefully give a better grip... Print using 0.2mm layers. I have included lots of versions with differently sized "loops" so that you can create your own preferred grip depending on your filament/speed etc. ( In the pics I have used PI-ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black http://rubber3dprinting.com/ ) Use the rims found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1103751 This snap-on design is also available for tires/rims that can be used with the OpenR/C Touring Car or similar RC cars naturally. Download the Touring rims here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001223 and the tires here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001233 Enjoy! Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/
http://palmiga.com/ Follow me on Instagram and/or twitter:
http://instagram.com/rubber3dprinting
https://twitter.com/rubber3dprint For more info regarding release of the F1 car and also the other Open-RC project head over in this direction: http://danielnoree.com/
For OpenR/C Formula 1 print-files (after release) go here: https://pinshape.com/users/18846-danielnoree
For my designs check out http://www.thingiverse.com/Palmiga/designs & https://www.instagram.com/rubber3dprinting/ Due to the nature of 3D printing / material used etc... Keep in mind that you use my designs on your own risk and that I in no way is responsible for any damage och injuries.

-Guide wires through the holes in the sides of the enclosure  
-Glue the bottom plate to the top piece  
Wall thickness of finished piece is 2mm on all sides, so you could set your software to utilize this wall thickness.

title: GoPro 3-axis gimbal for Tarot 680Pro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3-axis gimbal for GoPro cameras, meant to be attached on standard mounts of Tarot 680Pro hexacopter. However it should fit to many other multicopters.
I use it with STorM32 BGC gimbal controller and Quanum 2208 stepper motors. Even if GoPro fit tight, it should be secured with additional strap.
For assembling you will need some M3 screws and nuts (for engine holders), screws to attach engines to its mounts, anti-vibration dampers and some CA glue to put some parts together (I designed them to be easy to print). Also you may need some M1.6 or M2 screws to attach oryginal pipe holders (black on photos; you can easily use CA glue instead and/or other small screws, just to support the glue).
First run with basic settings of STorM32 BGC gimbal controller Overall view Gimbal with STorM32 BGC mounted on top

description.text:
I've tried several spool holders that either didn't print well or work as described. The part dimensions were incorrect, so after hours of printing the thing became file 13, or once assembled and the spool was installed, the spool fell off and my unattended print went wrong. Solution... Design and print my own design and proof it before giving it to the masses. So here you go a spool holder designed and assembled in solidworks prior to printing and able to handle full sized 1kg rolls up to 95mm or 3.74" wide, since there's a wide variety of spool designs on the market from different vendors.
The design is simple with Two vertical supports and two spool spindle pins and only one of the remaining parts all printed in ABS. The spool spindle pins are designed with slight draft angle to allow for easy assembly and spool changes. Another great invention for my 3d printer here at Bullseye Body, LLC. This tool aids in first article proofing prior to production run injection molding. In my spare time I like to tweak designs to enable the printer to work more efficiently.
Enjoy and post photos of your prints and comments if this was a helpful design for your printing needs! HAPPY PRINTING!

Printer:

PrusaI3 Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15%

Once cooled and removed from the bed, I assembled the pieces and secured the spreader bar to the uprights with a small amount of acetone injected into the joint with a needle while holding the design square to the surface.
Solidworks 2016

  • 808 wedge: 30 degree camera wedge for your camera. 808 fits nicely, runcam and mobius fit as well. a gopro mount is coming

  • led bar - adds a 8 W2812 LED bar to the back of the top plate. I've also installed an extra polulu voltage regulator inside of this mount.

author: rverlaine

description.text: Net for an Icosahedron (20 sided shape). I have entered it in to the maker ed challenge as I think it could be used to teach Infant/ Junior school children about shapes and what a net is. Much simpler shapes could be created this is just one example. I used a 0.4mm thickness between triangles to act as hinges and then used glue to stick it together. It is a fast build, took about 40 mins.

Objectives: Children of a Junior school age learning about shapes and nets of shapes in an interactive way.
Audiences: Junior school age.
Preparation: Students should have an understanding of 3D nets and be shown the example of the 20 sided shape and be challenged to make cubes or different simpler shapes.
Steps: Students can be taught how to use design software, as it is a simple design any software could be used and then the students would print their net and see if it made a successful shape.

description.text:
Thank you to jeanmariecannie for coming up with the original Gimbal Lock. I recaptured the design and updated it for the 2.7K camera that comes on the advanced and standard model Phantom 3s.  Enjoy.
1/16/2016 - Made an update to give the clip room to flex down.  Also extended the camera cover by 4.5mm to more completely cover the camera.  New model uploaded replacing the original.
1/17/2016 - Updated the print in place hinge area to allow for more clearance so the plastic between the two parts does not fuse during printing on some printers.  New model uploaded replacing the original.

  • Added a mount for an inductive sensor 4mm to the side of the backet

  • Made the top layer of the circular duct bigger to remove holes in prints

This is a depth gauge stand for a Replicator 1, Replicator 2, or a Wanhao Duplicator 4 3D printer. I assume it can also be customized to work with any box type FFF printer where the extruder is mounted on 2 parallel rails.
The bridge sits on the rails, and a depth gauge fits through the hole in the middle. This enables one to get height readings quickly of the height of the build plate. 
UPDATE: I tried it. It kinda works. It doesn't wrap around the rails nicely, and needs some pressure. The problem is, the pressure required bends the rails too. I ended up using a piece of wood with a hole drilled in it.

title: Hobbyking / Starmax Piper J3 Cub 1400mm Replacement Parts

description.text:
This model gets very good reviews for its flight characteristics but it has a few weak points. As I built it, I designed some parts to address these areas. Then, as I crashed it, I also added some replacement parts. These parts should also work for the L-4 Grasshopper sold by Hobbyking as it is the same model with a different paint job. If you don't own a printer, you can upload the files to me via 3Dhubs and I can print them and ship them to you: https://www.3dhubs.com/trenton/hubs/cbl. (Or you can choose from other printers in your area on 3Dhubs and save on shipping.) My replacement and improvement pack consists of:

  • Landing Gear Left, Right, and Cover - The main parts of the landing gear are two triangular pieces of thin plastic. They will break. I've made reinforced replacements for them.

  • Landing Gear Cross Brace - If you are not worried about the scale look, you can print this using Ninjaflex Semiflex and string it between the two axles to act like a giant rubber band / shock absorber. It is designed to replace all the fiddly little springs and flimsy plastic parts which look like they will break if you sneeze on them.

  • Landing Gear Hold Down Plate - The front of the landing gear, which consists of the metal bar that also serves as the axles, is "attached" to the plane by pressing it into a plastic slot. It is likely that during a rough or uneven landing, this will come out and the landing gear will fold backward and shear off, probably ripping off your wing supports along the way. This part and three small screws should save you from that.

  • Landing Gear Mounting Plate - This is the plastic part that is embedded in the foam underbelly to which the landing gear is mounted. There is no reason to use my version over the stock, it only serves as a replacement if yours is damaged. My version is identical to stock except for the addition of the three holes used for mounting the Landing Gear Hold Down Plate.

  • Elevator Bridge Stiffener - The elevator is just foam, and the control horn attaches to the right side of the elevator. The skinny bit of foam that connects the left and right sides of the elevator (the bridge) is too flexible, so the right side is going to actuate more than the left. I'm no aerospace engineer, but I think that is a bad thing. Glue this stiffener to the under side of the elevator and you won't have to find out how bad.

  • Battery Cover - The stock one is probably fine, but I chiseled away some of the height of the battery compartment in order for the battery to actually fit, which left the front of the cover (the part held by a tab) too loose. If you are in a similar pickle, this thing is for you.

  • Wing Latch - This is the clear plastic part that gets sandwiched between the two wing halves. It forms the top of the cockpit and the sun roof. Its main function in the model is to provide a tab that fits into a slot in the front of the cockpit in order to hold down the front of the wing. My version should be more or less identical to stock and is only needed if yours is broken.

  • Wing Struts - The plastic pieces that brace the main wing. I broke up the main strut on each side into three pieces so they will fit on most print beds.

  • Skis! - These worked great on icy-crusted snow. However, they may be too small for deep, fluffy snow. Thanks to the built-in leaf springs, they are designed to be used without the need for external springs to keep them level during flight.

  • Hub Cap / Wheel Nut - You know, the plastic part that holds the wheel on. I gave up style for functionality on this one. Instead of saying "CUB" on it, I made it 2mm thicker with a "+" slot on it so that you can use a flat-head screwdriver or even a coin to tighten it.

  • Hub Cap Cub - A more stock rendition of the hub cap with the "CUB" text on it.

  • Wing Strut Anchor - The plastic part that gets glued to the underside of the main wing to which the wing struts are attached. If that doesn't make sense, just look at the part and you'll get it :) These should be pretty close to stock except I did not bother with the slight curve to the top surface.

  • Tail Strut Anchor - Same thing as the Wing Strut Anchor, only smaller. These go on the horizontal and vertical wings as mounting points for the springs that supposedly reinforce this section. These are pretty close to stock except I beefed up the loop in the hopes that this will actually be printable. I haven't tried it yet.

  • Steering Holder - This clips on to the bottom of the rudder to steer the rear wheel. Mine should be pretty near to stock.
    • EDIT 1/17/2016
    Renamed "Landing Gear Mounting Plate" to "Landing Gear Hold Down Plate" EDIT 1/18/2016
    Added "Landing Gear Mounting Plate" and "Wing Latch" EDIT 1/19/2016
    Added "Landing Gear Left, Right, and Cover" EDIT 1/21/2016
    Added "Landing Gear Cover with Mount Right" and "Landing Gear Cover with Mount Left" EDIT 1/23/2016
    Added "Wing Strut Left (A)", "Wing Strut Left (B)", "Wing Strut Left (C)", "Wing Strut Inclined Left", "Wing Strut Right (A)", "Wing Strut Right (B)", "Wing Strut Right (C)", "Wing Strut Inclined Right" Modified "Landing Gear Mounting Plate". Increased depth of landing gear / strut mounting area by 0.4mm to match original. EDIT 1/29/2016
    Added "Ski Main Left", "Ski Main Right", and "Ski Tail". EDIT 2/5/2016
    Added "Hub Cap", "Hub Cap Cub", and "Wing Strut Anchor" EDIT 2/13/2016
    Added "Tail Strut Anchor" and "Steering Holder"
    Re-uploaded "Ski Tail" with the correct orientation for printing (on its side).

Landing Gear Left, Right, and Cover Print these fairly solid. You will need one Left, one Right, and two Covers. If you don't need the mounts for the flimsy springs of the stock suspension, then the plain cover works for both sides if you flip it over. If you are going for the scale look and need the mounts, you will need to print one of each "Landing Gear Cover with Mount". After printing, install the left and right sides into the wire frame just like the stock parts. There is no need to glue these - simply install the cover with three M3 x 6 screws (or shorter) and Bob is your uncle. Landing Gear Cross Brace Print in Ninjaflex Semiflex. You will probably need to rotate by 45 degrees to fit on print bed. Print it solid, and I suggest a minimum of 1.5mm of shell so the brace prints as long continuous rubber "threads". In other words, cross hatching would be weaker. To install, simply remove the wheels, slide onto one axle, then stretch it and slide over the other axle. Landing Gear Hold Down Plate Print solid. ABS would probably be best. Put it in place. The side with the bump goes down over the bar to keep it down inside the channel. Mark the locations of the holes. Drill slightly smaller holes than the screws you intend to use. I used 3mm button heads. Landing Gear Mounting Plate Print this solid. In ABS, mine weighed just slightly less than stock. You will need to use support. To install, simply glue in place. White Gorilla Glue worked for me. Elevator Bridge Stiffener Print solid, ABS would probably be best. Remove the rudder and elevator. Glue the stiffener to the underside of the elevator. White Gorilla Glue works like a champ. Clamp it in place as it dries. Be careful to protect the top side of the elevator from the clamp. I used binder clips and they left grooves. Once dry, put it all back together. Battery Cover Print this as light as you dare, preferably in ABS. You will need support (for the tab). I used a 0.5mm shell thickness (one layer), a top/bottom thickness of 1mm, and a fill density of 10%. After it is printed, trial fit it. If it works for you, remove the magnet from the old foam cover and glue it in place on the new cover. It's best to clamp it in place as it dries. I used White Gorilla Glue for this, but just about anything would work. Wing Latch Print solid. You will probably want to use support unless you want to try to bridge the top. Install just like the original. Wing Struts You will need to print parts A, B, C, and Inclined for each side. Parts A, B,and C will need to be glued together in some way, either by traditional glues, epoxies, or acetone if you print with ABS, which I recommend. You will want to print these pretty solid. I would use support for part A. You may also find it beneficial to have your fan turn on for the last layers of all the parts because they have some small details (like loops) that will become blobs without it. I wouldn't use the fan all the time, however, as it will make the parts want to warp. Skis Print all three skis on their sides with support. At least two shells is recommended, but you can use about 10% fill. All three are bolt-on replacements for the stock wheels. As always with 3D printing, it might be necessary to drill the mounting holes out bigger after printing. Hub Cap / Wheel Nut Print solid, no support needed. Since it is a small part, I suggest printing in a lower temperature with the fan on. You might also need to add a brim to get good adhesion to the bed. I made mine using PET since I found ABS to be too soft so that the slots would get easily mangled by the screwdriver. You can probably use PLA too in a pinch. Wing Strut Anchor Print solid with support. I haven't printed these yet. I think ABS would be fine. You will probably have to have your fan kick on for the top part (mounting tabs). I used White Gorilla Glue to mount my originals, which I have yet to have to replace (knock on wood). Tail Strut Anchor Print solid with support. I haven't printed these yet. I think ABS would be fine. You will probably have to have your fan kick on for the top part (mounting loop). I used White Gorilla Glue to mount my originals, which I have yet to have to replace (knock on wood). Steering Holder Print solid with no support. Install just like stock.

comments.text: Glad I stumbled across your parts. I just bought a printer recently and never thought about printing parts for this plane. My cub had a not so good landing last summer and it has been sitting on a shelf in pieces since. I have the landing gear all printed out and fits nice. Will be printing out the wing struts soon, gluing a piece of foam, and ordering a prop mount then should be back in the sky. Hopefully for more than 5 flights this time. Thank you sir for taking the time to make these parts and sharing them
comments.author: Madmax0509

comments.text: I appreciate the thank you, and I wish you luck and happy flying with the new parts. I'm actually going to dust my Cub off tomorrow and give it an airing. Cheers!
comments.author: Madmax0509

comments.text:
Interesting take on the skis. Flying skis this winter for the first time, I find no matter what size the skis, you need a thin skim of snow on the ground or crust on top. So going smaller is a good thing, you would need monstrous skis to actually carry the weight on soft snow more than a couple of inches deep. As we are supposed to get up to 2' overnight, tonight, I may get some more flights in on the weekend.
Also, your landing gear clamp looks like a good idea- make them break-away for hard landings and just carry a bunch with you to the field.
comments.author: BigSpud

comments.text: I've heard of people successfully using floats in the snow. We were supposed to get about 12" of snow here in central NJ, but thankfully it turned to rain about 1/4 the way through. It's still cold, windy, and generally miserable however.

As a Retired USAF Aircraft Tech and long time RC aircraft pilot I assure you that YES, Elevator Flex is BAD. It causes a roll input coupled from elevator input. On this plane it would make the Plane roll left on Up elevator and Right on Down input. (As viewed from Behind)

title: Filament Spool Roller for 2020 Aluminum Extrusion

description.text:
My FolgerTech 2020 just has a 2020 extruded aluminum bar on which the filament spool rolls. There's quite a lot of resistance to the spool rolling and my extruder was working pretty hard to pull filament off the roll. I designed a bearing which slots over the extruded aluminum and allows the spool to roll freely. The outside roller has a step in it to fit against the edge of the roller so you need two of these rollers for each spool. 
I used two 4-40 x 3/8" pan head screws, two 4-40 nuts, and a handful of 1/8" ball bearings.
The bearings seem rough at first but are perfectly adequate after you break them in. Designed using OnShape. Fits minimum spool diameter of 43mm.

author: Delphius

title: Cities and Knights Game Piece Holders

description.text: The Cities and Knights expansions set for the Settlers of Catan provide lousy zip-lock bags to carry all the goodies that it comes with. That's barely passable - so I made these to make it much better. Whether you have the 4 player base game set or the 6 player expansion, these boxes (with snap-on lids) will keep them all organized and neatly presentable when it comes to game time! The design of these (and everything I organize actually) is greatly inspired by key elements of konmari - to store things vertically and presentably!! All pieces are visible at a glance and can be retrieved and stored easily. I've added notches on the sides so that fingers can easily grab all of them in a row at once (without having to flip it over and dump them all out). The game pieces are happier this way. One box holds all the knights and the other holds all the city walls. Feel free to check out my other designs which are as diverse as they are many: http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

author: 3E8

title: Wireless NES Controller Case and Receiver Box

description.text: This is the back of the NES controller, with added depth for supporting electronics, and a simple box for the receiver. I used this model in my wireless NES controller project, over on my blog. http://poorstudenthobbyist.blogspot.com/ I use two ATMega328s and a wireless transmitter and receiver to wirelessly communicate between the controller and the NES. Check it out and my other electronics tutorials!

I'm not sure if the dimensions of this is correct - I have to convert the model to inches when I go to print it on my printer. For reference, the controller should be about 5 inches long, and the receiver box and lid are about 2" x 2.75". For those who do not want a hole for the switch, I provided a model without the hole, so that you can make your own.

Es handelt sich hier um ein Adaptersystem um Hotends der Firma e3d-online.com am
X-carriage des RepRapPro Ormerod befestigen zu können.
(Ich empfehle die aktuelle Version des X-carriage zu verwenden)
Es stehen drei Basisbefestigungen mit unterschiedlichen Eigenschaften zur Verfügung: base_a :
Diese Variante ermöglich lediglich die Befestigung des Hotends
Achtung, mit dieser Variante muss "clamp_a" verwendet werden. base_b:
Diese Variante ermöglich neben der Befestigung des Hotends ausserdem die Befestigung der zum Hotend führenden Kabel, so wie einer Kühlluftzufuhr. base_c:
Diese Variante bietet zusätzlich die Möglichkeit den zum Hotend führenden bowdentube definiert zu führen und diesen zu fixieren. Folgendes Material kommt zusätzlich zum Einsatz: Für die Hotend-Klemmung:
2x Zylinderkopfschraube M3x25 bis M3x30(max!) Für die Klemmung der Kühlluftleitung:
1x Zylinderkopfschraube M3x8 bis M3x10
(Hier sind auch andere Schraubenköpfe möglich) Für die Verschraubung des Bowdenclips:
1x Zylinderkopfschraube M3x10 bis M3x12
(Hier sind auch andere Schraubenköpfe möglich) 3 bis 4 Muttern M3 (Je nach Verwendung) 3 bis 5 kleine Kabelbinder (Je nach Verwendung) Ausserdem werden 2 Schrauben benötigt um die Halterung am X-carriage zu befestigen.
(Eventuell lassen sich die Originalteile wiederverwenden) Die Fotos zeigen eine Vorgängerversion, die Hauptmerkmale sind aber gleich geblieben.
Die Optimierungen betreffen vor allem die Anbauteile. Die OpenSCAD Datei ist ausführlich kommentiert und ermöglicht eine leichte Anpassung der Modelle an eigene Bedürfnisse. Update 16.01.2016 20:30

This a Re-Engineered CAD model for the yolk assembly, this along with the other uploads I'll be making periodically will complete the making of a complete Headband Assembly, CD3000 is a discontinued model and I thought I'll make these CAD models open to the public for free who could potentially service/repair their pair. This design was made by my Co-Worker - Mr. Sachin Shedge so all the design credit goes to him, he is not active on the internet, especially on forums so it's my responsibility to give relevant credit. As far as the model is concerned, I suggest increasing the scale by 0.1-0.2X depending on whether or not you want it to encompass the Interior Assembly but keep in mind this might affect the articulation since the side tab diameter increase could hinder entry into the Earcup. This shouldn't be used to service the Sony MDR-R10 as the Yolk assemblies are altered but they could be used if you really want to, I wouldn't use it though. The imperfection below the "I" is not noticeable when printed but I will update and add a link to the corrected model once fixed. Update 1 - This update is related to the scale, I found just increasing the height from 85mm to 90mm solved the fit issue, this is good if you don't want to mess with the scale which has a negative issue on other things. I suggest just increasing the height or depth depending on how you place the model in the slicer from 85mm to 90mm and then you should have a perfect fit. Update 2 - The new file added as of 19 January, 2016 makes the "I" a bit thicker, I faced into a problems regarding snapping so I made the thickness half that of the body which will be uploaded soon.
This thickened I makes the structural integrity much higher but negatively affects the articulation play, mathematically it should be 50% less which is enough but I would have liked it to be higher.
If you are CNCing or using Carbon Fibre PLA, I suggest you play around with the original file and test for yourself. Update 3 - The newest and final file has been added as of 20-1-16, this fixes the lines that were previously there.

author: ewap

title: MPCNC drag chain / cable carrier for XY-axis

description.text: This is a cable carrier AKA "drag chain" for the MPCNC machine X and Y axis. It mounts under the roller block so there is no extra width added to the frame. The Z axis is here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1296042 The plate hole pattern fits a 10x15 chain carrier available from Amazon. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00880AVL2?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00 This chain is installed now, so I know it works, but I may be upsizing to a 10x30 because there are a lot of cables coming from the extruder head.A router head may not need the larger cable carrier. The design of this plate will allow most any cable carrier to fit, as it is a simple plate mount. I have a version with and without holes, so you can make your own holes as needed. I also checked the fit for the IE version on my CAD software and it looks like it will fit that as well with no mods. If someone with an IE machine can verify the physical fit in the comments that would be great. Update- It does work with the IE version! Extra hardware needed: To install, simply replace the four 1.25" mounting bolts with 1.5" bolts. I also used four 6-32 x .5" flat head screws and lock nuts to mount my drag chain, your chain may be different.

Notes: 3 walls, tops, and bottoms. You will need supports. I recommend printing two at a time. I used PLA.

You may have to drill out the holes slightly for an easy fit.  As it is comes off my printer, the bolts will screw in, but not push in.  A 5/16 drill bit is perfect.
I also had to do a bit of cleanup on the overhangs, but it was no big deal and they can't really be seen anyway.

This is a tool I made based on the idea I saw at http://weldingweb.com/showthread.php?168191-Internal-o-ring-inserter-tool My '71 John Deere 4320 tractor has some hydraulic dowel pins (JD part R41511) that (during a clutch replacement) require a new o-ring (JD part R56464) to be inserted inside a small shaft in the support unit (JD part AR40572). I spent hours unable to get even one in with the tools I had.

Notes: The only part that needs support is the plug. The finger needs to be 100% infill, but at .2mm and 3 perimeters, it is made solid regardless of infill settings, so all items can be sliced together.

Attach the Handle The handle can be attached with superglue (PLA), or acetone (ABS). Leave the plug loose from the shell, to allow some adjusting of the insertion depth. To increase the depth, add shims above the plug. To decrease the insertion depth, don't press the shell flat against the opening.
Parameters I wrote the .scad file to be parametric for Oring depth, Oring thickness, Internal diameter and gap between parts. It should be easily modified for other sizes of o-rings and holes.

description.text:
The Desktop Defender is a 5 shot automatic catapult. When your in need to defend your cubicle from the perils of office warfare, the desktop defender is a one man army.
check out the video:
http://youtu.be/nL_UauU9k9w

print each file
pivot_arm (x5) pivot_rod (x1) Friction_fit_pin (x2) left_vertical_support (x1) right_vertical_support (x1) Base (x1) crossbar (x1) basket (x5) 8mm_spacer (x2) 25mm_spacer (x4) no support needed assemble vertical supports on both sides of base
attach crossbar with friction fit pins
slide pivot rod thru one side of the base then thru 8mm spacer,then pivot arm, then 25mm spacer followed by pivot arm (x4), then thru last 8mm spacer and thru the other end of base
glue basket to end of each pivot arm create pulling pins out of paperclips (5 total)
need 5 rubber bands and attach from crossbar to each arm hook Aim...Fire...Enjoy

title: Flash Forge Creator Pro - active cooling fan holder

description.text:
Snap on 40mm nozzle fan holder. I'm using mostly the right extruder so that's what I build this for.
But there is also left version and a center one.
I'm not sure how good the center version works as the fan is blowing between the two nozzles. It simply snaps into the two small holes on top of the extruder carriage. Screw the 40mm 24v fan with two little 2.5mm screws to the holder and connect the fan cable to the unpopulated FET6 connector on the Mightyboard. Especially PLA print quality is much improved with a nozzle fan!
Notes: Print with ABS as PLA might melt or get soft because of the short distance to the nozzles.
